abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Economic Management
            Technical Assistance Project for Bangladesh were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was low or negligible, Bank performance
            was unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory. Country systems need to be fully understood
            if they are to be incorporated into design. The team was
            aware that components will be subject to the Technical
            Project Proposal (TPP) approval process, and made
            suggestions as to how that process could be simplified. In
            the event, improvements were not taken up, and the slow
            working of TPPs was one of the main factors in
            unsatisfactory project performance. There are existing
            public administration constraints to how effectively a
            Government uses external Technical Assistance (TA).
            Bangladesh civil service's frequent rotation of staff
            undermines continuity of management, resulting in
            implementation delays. The practice of embedding project
            component management in existing agency structures is in
            principle sound, but in practice is undermined by
            counterpart staff holding several jobs at the same time,
            leading them to see project management as an extra
            responsibility. The procurement of consultant studies,
            training, and Information and Communication Technology (ICT)
            purchases should be routine functions of Government
            agencies, but were viewed additional burdens. Awareness of
            these constraints should inform the future design of
            projects. Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) systems need
            to be simple and meaningful. A diversified TA project with
            components of modest size and dependent on country systems
            for implementation can become unwieldy and beyond
            implementing agency capacity, if the Bank's standard
            approach to M&E is applied to each component.
            Furthermore, applying the Bank's results based approach
            to monitoring a project where the focus is on improving the
            machinery of government (as opposed to direct service
            delivery) is inherently difficult.
